questions.notes: A common assumption among art historians is that the invention of photography in the mid-nineteenth century displaced the painted portrait in the public consciousness. The diminishing popularity of the portrait miniature, which coincided with the rise of photography, seems to support this claim. However, photography’s impact on the portrait miniature may be overstated. Although records from art exhibitions in the Netherlands from 1820 to 1892 show a decrease in the number of both full-sized and miniature portraits submitted, this trend was established before the invention of photography.
questions.question: Based on the text, what can be concluded about the diminishing popularity of the portrait miniature in the nineteenth century?

answer_choices.A: Factors other than the rise of photography may be more directly responsible for the portrait miniature’s decline.
answer_choices.B: Although portrait miniatures became less common than photographs, they were widely regarded as having more artistic merit.
answer_choices.C: The popularity of the portrait miniature likely persisted for longer than art historians have assumed.
answer_choices.D: As demand for portrait miniatures decreased, portrait artists likely shifted their creative focus to photography.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The text indicates that the impact of photography might be overstated since the decline in portrait miniatures began before photography’s invention, implying that other factors may have driven the decline.

questions.notes: Believing that living in an impractical space can heighten awareness and even improve health, conceptual artists Madeline Gins and Shusaku Arakawa designed an apartment building in Japan to be more fanciful than functional. A kitchen counter is chest-high on one side and knee-high on the other; a ceiling has a door to nowhere. The effect is disorienting but invigorating: after four years there, filmmaker Nobu Yamaoka reported significant health benefits.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Although inhabiting a home surrounded by fanciful features such as those designed by Gins and Arakawa can be rejuvenating, it is unsustainable.
answer_choices.B: Designing disorienting spaces like those in the Gins and Arakawa building is the most effective way to create a physically stimulating environment.
answer_choices.C: As a filmmaker, Yamaoka has long supported the designs of conceptual artists such as Gins and Arakawa.
answer_choices.D: Although impractical, the design of the apartment building by Gins and Arakawa may improve the well-being of the apartment building’s residents.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it accurately reflects that despite the building’s impractical design, it has the potential to improve the residents' well-being, as supported by Yamaoka’s reported health benefits.

questions.notes: The most recent iteration of the immersive theater experience Sleep No More, which premiered in New York City in 2011, transforms its performance space—a five-story warehouse—into a 1930s-era hotel. Audience members, who wander through the labyrinthine venue at their own pace and follow the actors as they play out simultaneous, interweaving narrative loops, confront the impossibility of experiencing the production in its entirety. The play’s refusal of narrative coherence thus hinges on the sense of spatial fragmentation that the venue’s immense and intricate layout generates.
questions.question: What does the text most strongly suggest about Sleep No More’s use of its performance space?

answer_choices.A: The choice of a New York City venue likely enabled the play’s creators to experiment with the use of theatrical space in a way that venues from earlier productions could not.
answer_choices.B: Audience members likely find the experience of the play disappointing because they generally cannot make their way through the entire venue.
answer_choices.C: The production’s dependence on a particular performance environment would likely make it difficult to reproduce exactly in a different theatrical space.
answer_choices.D: Audience members who navigate the space according to a recommended itinerary will likely have a better grasp of the play’s narrative than audience members who depart from that itinerary.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. The text emphasizes that the production’s effect relies heavily on the unique, intricate layout of its performance space, implying that replicating the production in another space would be challenging.

questions.notes: Utah is home to Pando, a colony of about 47,000 quaking aspen trees that all share a single root system. Pando is one of the largest single organisms by mass on Earth, but ecologists are worried that its growth is declining in part because of grazing by animals. The ecologists say that strong fences could prevent deer from eating young trees and help Pando start thriving again.
questions.question: According to the text, why are ecologists worried about Pando?

answer_choices.A: It isn’t growing at the same rate it used to.
answer_choices.B: It isn’t producing young trees anymore.
answer_choices.C: It can’t grow into new areas because it is blocked by fences.
answer_choices.D: Its root system can’t support many more new trees.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text states that ecologists are concerned that Pando’s growth is declining—implying that it is not growing at the rate it once did.

questions.notes:
The following text is from Jane Austen’s 1811 novel Sense and Sensibility. Elinor lives with her younger sisters and her mother, Mrs. Dashwood.
Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified her, though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her mother, and enabled her frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all, that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence. She had an excellent heart;—her disposition was affectionate, and her feelings were strong; but she knew how to govern them: it was a knowledge which her mother had yet to learn; and which one of her sisters had resolved never to be taught.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Elinor?

answer_choices.A: Elinor often argues with her mother but fails to change her mind.
answer_choices.B: Elinor can be overly sensitive with regard to family matters.
answer_choices.C: Elinor thinks her mother is a bad role model.
answer_choices.D: Elinor is remarkably mature for her age.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text highlights that, despite being only nineteen, Elinor possesses a high level of understanding and judgment, making her exceptionally mature.

questions.notes: Biologists have predicted that birds’ feather structures vary with habitat temperature, but this hadn’t been tested in mountain environments. Ornithologist Sahas Barve studied feathers from 249 songbird species inhabiting different elevations—and thus experiencing different temperatures—in the Himalaya Mountains. He found that feathers of high-elevation species not only have a greater proportion of warming downy sections to flat and smooth sections than do feathers of low-elevation species, but high-elevation species’ feathers also tend to be longer, providing a thicker layer of insulation.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Barve’s investigation shows that some species of Himalayan songbirds have evolved feathers that better regulate body temperature than do the feathers of other species, contradicting previous predictions.
answer_choices.B: Barve found an association between habitat temperature and feather structure among Himalayan songbirds, lending new support to a general prediction.
answer_choices.C: Barve discovered that songbirds have adapted to their environment by growing feathers without flat and smooth sections, complicating an earlier hypothesis.
answer_choices.D: The results of Barve’s study suggest that the ability of birds to withstand cold temperatures is determined more strongly by feather length than feather structure, challenging an established belief.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text describes an association between habitat temperature and feather structure among Himalayan songbirds, thereby lending support to the general prediction that birds’ feather structures vary with habitat temperature.

questions.notes: Paleontologists searching for signs of ancient life have found many fossilized specimens of prehistoric human ancestors, including several from the Pleistocene era discovered in a geological formation in the Minatogawa quarry in Japan. However, to study the emergence of the earliest multicellular organisms to appear on Earth, researchers must turn elsewhere, such as to the Ediacaran geological formation at Mistaken Point in Canada. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the 146-hectare reserve contains more than 10,000 fossils that together document a critical moment in evolutionary history.
questions.question: What does the text indicate about the geological formation at Mistaken Point?

answer_choices.A: It holds a greater number of fossils but from a smaller variety of species than the formation in the Minatogawa quarry does.
answer_choices.B: It has provided evidence that the earliest human species may have emerged before the Pleistocene era.
answer_choices.C: It is widely considered by paleontologists to be the most valuable source of information about prehistoric life forms.
answer_choices.D: It contains specimens from an older time period than those found in the formation in the Minatogawa quarry.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The text explains that Mistaken Point preserves fossils of the earliest multicellular organisms, implying that these fossils date from an older period than the Pleistocene-era fossils found at the Minatogawa quarry.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Johanna Spyri’s 1881 novel Heidi (translated by Elisabeth Stork in 1915). Eight-year-old Heidi and her friend’s grandmother are looking at some illustrated books.
Heidi had come and was looking with wondering eyes at the splendid pictures in the large books, that Grandmama was showing her. Suddenly she screamed aloud, for there on the picture she saw a peaceful flock grazing on a green pasture. In the middle a shepherd was standing, leaning on his crook. The setting sun was shedding a golden light over everything. With glowing eyes Heidi devoured the scene.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Heidi is upset until she sees a serene image of a pasture in one of Grandmama’s books.
answer_choices.B: Heidi is delighted and fascinated by an image she sees in one of Grandmama’s books.
answer_choices.C: Heidi is initially frightened by an image in one of Grandmama’s books but quickly comes to appreciate its beauty.
answer_choices.D: Heidi is inspecting an image in one of Grandmama’s books because she has never seen a shepherd with his sheep before.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text shows that Heidi reacts with delight and fascination when she sees the peaceful, radiant image of the pasture.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Edgar Allan Poe’s 1849 story “Landor’s Cottage.”
During a pedestrian trip last summer, through one or two of the river counties of New York, I found myself, as the day declined, somewhat embarrassed about the road I was pursuing. The land undulated very remarkably; and my path, for the last hour, had wound about and about so confusedly, in its effort to keep in the valleys, that I no longer knew in what direction lay the sweet village of B——, where I had determined to stop for the night.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The narrator remembers a trip he took and admits to getting lost.
answer_choices.B: The narrator recalls fond memories of a journey that he took through some beautiful river counties.
answer_choices.C: The narrator describes what he saw during a long trip through a frequently visited location.
answer_choices.D: The narrator explains the difficulties he encountered on a trip and how he overcame them.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The narrator expresses embarrassment over his confused, winding path that ultimately left him lost as he sought his destination.

questions.notes: In 1934, physicist Eugene Wigner posited the existence of a crystal consisting entirely of electrons in a honeycomb-like structure. The so-called Wigner crystal remained largely conjecture, however, until Feng Wang and colleagues announced in 2021 that they had captured an image of one. The researchers trapped electrons between two semiconductors and then cooled the apparatus, causing the electrons to settle into a crystalline structure. By inserting an ultrathin sheet of graphene above the crystal, the researchers obtained an impression—the first visual confirmation of the Wigner crystal.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Researchers have obtained the most definitive evidence to date of the existence of the Wigner crystal.
answer_choices.B: Researchers have identified an innovative new method for working with unusual crystalline structures.
answer_choices.C: Graphene is the most important of the components required to capture an image of a Wigner crystal.
answer_choices.D: It’s difficult to acquire an image of a Wigner crystal because of the crystal’s honeycomb structure.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text details how the long-hypothesized Wigner crystal was finally confirmed visually through a novel experimental method.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from María Cristina Mena’s 1914 short story “The Vine-Leaf.”
It is a saying in the capital of Mexico that Dr. Malsufrido carries more family secrets under his hat than any archbishop. The doctor’s hat is, appropriately enough, uncommonly capacious, rising very high, and sinking so low that it seems to be supported by his ears and eyebrows, and it has a furry look, as if it had been brushed the wrong way, which is perhaps what happens to it if it is ever brushed at all. When the doctor takes it off, the family secrets do not fly out like a flock of parrots, but remain nicely bottled up beneath a dome of old and highly polished ivory.
questions.question: Based on the text, how do people in the capital of Mexico most likely regard Dr. Malsufrido?

answer_choices.A: Many have come to tolerate him despite his disheveled appearance.
answer_choices.B: Few feel concerned that he will divulge their confidences.
answer_choices.C: Some dislike how freely he discusses his own family.
answer_choices.D: Most would be unimpressed by him were it not for his professional expertise.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text uses a humorous metaphor to suggest that Dr. Malsufrido keeps secrets well, so people do not worry about their confidences being revealed.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Countee Cullen’s 1926 poem “Thoughts in a Zoo.”
They in their cruel traps, and we in ours, 
Survey each other’s rage, and pass the hours 
Commiserating each the other’s woe, 
To mitigate his own pain’s fiery glow. 
Man could but little proffer in exchange 
Save that his cages have a larger range. 
That lion with his lordly, untamed heart 
Has in some man his human counterpart, 
Some lofty soul in dreams and visions wrapped, 
But in the stifling flesh securely trapped.
questions.question: Based on the text, what challenge do humans sometimes experience?

answer_choices.A: They cannot effectively tame certain wild animals because of a lack of compassion.
answer_choices.B: They cannot focus on setting attainable goals because of a lack of motivation.
answer_choices.C: They quickly become frustrated when faced with difficult tasks because of a lack of self-control.
answer_choices.D: They have aspirations that cannot be fulfilled because of certain limitations.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The text metaphorically compares humans to animals in cages, suggesting that despite lofty aspirations, humans are limited by physical and societal constraints.

questions.notes: In superfluorescence, electrical charges known as dipoles emit light in synchronized bursts so intense that they are visible to the eye. Until recently, this phenomenon has only been observed at extremely cold temperatures because dipoles cannot synchronize at higher temperatures. But in a study, Melike Biliroglu and colleagues observed superfluorescence at room temperature in thin films made of perovskite and other similarly crystalline materials; the researchers propose that the formation of shock-absorbing quasiparticles called polarons in the material protects dipoles from thermal interference.
questions.question: Based on the text, how are polarons believed to be involved in the superfluorescence observed in Biliroglu and colleagues’ study?

answer_choices.A: Polarons enable superfluorescent bursts to cross from one crystalline material to another.
answer_choices.B: Polarons allow for the dipoles to synchronize despite higher temperatures.
answer_choices.C: Polarons accelerate the dipoles’ release of superfluorescent bursts.
answer_choices.D: Polarons decrease the intensity of the superfluorescent burst.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text explains that polarons help protect dipoles from thermal interference, allowing them to synchronize at room temperature and produce superfluorescence.

questions.notes: Scent is tightly interwoven with our daily lives, often evoking significant memories and important social events. This connection is of growing interest to archaeologists who hope to use it to better understand ancient rituals, trade, social hierarchies, and medicine. Although the speed at which odor molecules dissipate makes identifying ancient scents challenging, advancements in biomolecular technologies show promise in unlocking ancient aromas from preserved artifacts. Archaeological studies making use of these advancements may provide new insights into past societies.
questions.question: According to the text, what is one reason some archaeologists are interested in recovering scents from ancient artifacts?

answer_choices.A: They are investigating whether people’s sense of smell has declined in recent centuries.
answer_choices.B: They believe the scents could illuminate important aspects of ancient life.
answer_choices.C: They think that ancient scents would be enjoyable to people today.
answer_choices.D: They hope to develop new medicines using ancient scent molecules.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text explains that archaeologists want to recover scents because these scents can offer insights into ancient rituals, trade, social hierarchies, and medicine—key aspects of ancient life.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Edith Nesbit’s 1906 novel The Railway Children.
Mother did not spend all her time in paying dull [visits] to dull ladies, and sitting dully at home waiting for dull ladies to pay [visits] to her. She was almost always there, ready to play with the children, and read to them, and help them to do their home-lessons. Besides this she used to write stories for them while they were at school, and read them aloud after tea, and she always made up funny pieces of poetry for their birthdays and for other great occasions.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Mother?

answer_choices.A: She wishes that more ladies would visit her.
answer_choices.B: Birthdays are her favorite special occasion.
answer_choices.C: She creates stories and poems for her children.
answer_choices.D: Reading to her children is her favorite activity.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text clearly mentions that Mother writes stories and makes up funny poetry for her children, highlighting her creative role in their lives.

questions.notes: Paleontologist Lucas E. Fiorelli and colleagues have reported the discovery at a mine in Brazil of several egg clutches, partially preserved single eggs, and egg shells from the Late Cretaceous period. The researchers have concluded that the area was once a nesting and breeding site for titanosaurs, a group of sauropod dinosaurs. The finding is significant given the previous lack of known nesting sites in northern regions of South America, which led many paleontologists to assume that titanosaurs migrated south to lay eggs.
questions.question: What does the text most strongly suggest about the site discovered by the researchers?

answer_choices.A: It is the earliest known example of a titanosaur nesting and breeding site.
answer_choices.B: It was very difficult to excavate given that it was discovered in a mine.
answer_choices.C: It may have been occupied by other sauropods in addition to titanosaurs.
answer_choices.D: It is farther north than any other nesting site discovered in South America.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text emphasizes that the significance of the discovery lies in the fact that nesting sites in northern South America were previously unknown, indicating that this site is situated farther north than other known sites.

questions.notes: Philadelphia’s Black Pearl Chamber Orchestra, founded by Jeri Lynne Johnson, performs classical music, from well-known compositions by Beethoven to contemporary works by Jessie Montgomery. For the orchestra’s iConduct! program, Johnson invites community members to learn some basic elements of conducting and then experience conducting the Black Pearl orchestra themselves.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The Black Pearl orchestra performs music from all over the world but mostly performs music composed by Philadelphians.
answer_choices.B: Johnson founded the Black Pearl orchestra to perform classical music by contemporary artist Jessie Montgomery.
answer_choices.C: The Black Pearl orchestra gives community members the chance to both listen to and participate in classical music performance.
answer_choices.D: Johnson has community members conduct an orchestra to demonstrate how difficult the task is.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text highlights that the orchestra not only performs classical music but also provides an opportunity for community members to learn about and engage with conducting, thus combining listening and active participation.

questions.notes: Several scholars have argued that conditions in England in the late ninth through early eleventh centuries—namely, burgeoning literacy amid running conflicts between England’s Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and Danish invaders—were especially conducive to the production of the Old English epic poem Beowulf, and they have dated the poem’s composition accordingly. It is not inconceivable that Beowulf emerged from such a context, but privileging contextual fit over the linguistic evidence of an eighth- or even seventh-century composition requires a level of justification that thus far has not been presented.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Although there are some grounds for believing that Beowulf was composed between the late ninth and early eleventh centuries, advocates for that view tend to rely on evidence that has been called into question by advocates for an earlier date.
answer_choices.B: Although several scholars have dated Beowulf to the late ninth through early eleventh centuries, others have argued that doing so privileges a controversial interpretation of the social conditions of the period.
answer_choices.C: Although Beowulf fits well with the historical context of England in the late ninth through early eleventh centuries, it fits equally well with the historical context of England in the seventh and eighth centuries.
answer_choices.D: Although the claim of a late ninth- through early eleventh-century composition date for Beowulf has some plausibility, advocates for the claim have not compellingly addressed evidence suggesting an earlier date.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it most accurately states the main idea of the text. The text explains that while a later composition date for Beowulf may seem plausible given the historical context, the linguistic evidence points to an earlier composition (seventh or even eighth century), and scholars favoring the later date have not provided adequate justification for ignoring the linguistic evidence.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Oscar Wilde’s 1891 novel The Picture of Dorian Gray. Dorian Gray is taking his first look at a portrait that Hallward has painted of him.
Dorian passed listlessly in front of his picture and turned towards it. When he saw it he drew back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure. A look of joy came into his eyes, as if he had recognized himself for the first time. He stood there motionless and in wonder, dimly conscious that Hallward was speaking to him, but not catching the meaning of his words. The sense of his own beauty came on him like a revelation. He had never felt it before.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Dorian?

answer_choices.A: He wants to know Hallward’s opinion of the portrait.
answer_choices.B: He is delighted by what he sees in the portrait.
answer_choices.C: He prefers portraits to other types of paintings.
answer_choices.D: He is uncertain of Hallward’s talent as an artist.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text describes Dorian’s positive and enthralled reaction to seeing his portrait—his cheeks flush with pleasure and his eyes fill with joy—indicating that he is delighted by what he sees.

questions.notes: For centuries, the widespread acknowledgment of the involvement of the cerebellum—a dense brain structure in vertebrates—in coordinating motor control in humans has hindered recognition of other possible functions of the structure. Neuroscience research from the last two decades now suggests that the cerebellum regulates emotion and social behavior, and recent research by Ilaria Carta and colleagues has identified a pathway connecting the cerebellum to a center for motivation and reward processing known as the ventral tegmental area (VTA).
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The recent verification of a pathway between the VTA and the cerebellum confirms the cerebellum’s long-suspected role in motor coordination.
answer_choices.B: Recent advances in the field of neuroscience have challenged widely accepted claims about the function of a pathway connecting the VTA and the cerebellum.
answer_choices.C: The cerebellum has primarily been thought to regulate motor functioning, but in recent years neuroscience researchers have been uncovering additional functions.
answer_choices.D: Technological limitations have historically hindered the study of the cerebellum, but the recent development of new technologies has led to greater insights into its functions.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text contrasts the traditional view that the cerebellum is solely involved in motor coordination with recent research suggesting it also plays a role in regulating emotion and social behavior, highlighting the discovery of a pathway linking it to the VTA.
